conclusion: Acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph.
For object B, the curve is sloping downward at the start, becomes horizontal at its lowest point, and then slopes upward more and more steeply.

premise: Acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph. For object B, the curve is sloping downward at the start.
conclusion: From t = 0 to t1, the slope (acceleration) is negative but is getting less negative (i.e. increasing).

premise: Acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph. For object B, the curve becomes horizontal at its lowest point.
conclusion: At t = t1, the slope is zero → acceleration is zero.

premise: Acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph. For object B, the curve slopes upward more and more steeply.
conclusion: From t1 to t2, the slope is positive and keeps getting steeper → acceleration is positive and increasing.

premise: From t = 0 to t1, the slope (acceleration) is negative but is getting less negative. At t = t1, the slope is zero → acceleration is zero. From t1 to t2, the slope is positive and keeps getting steeper → acceleration is positive and increasing.
conclusion: Over the entire interval 0 → t2, the acceleration of object B increases continuously: it starts negative, rises to zero at t1, and continues to rise to a positive value by t2.
